text: loled at this from the athens MTG facebook group

I have a question for anyone who is more familiar with statistics than me:

Scenario, using the classic set-up:
I’m pulling 3 marbles from a bag without replacement. 4/15 are blue. If I want to find the total probability of pulling exactly 1, 2, or 3 blue marbles, can I just add their individual probabilities of picking exactly 1, 2, or 3?
Not exactly.
Wait, are you pulling one at a time?
Or all three at once?
You’re effectively pulling all three at once.
no, you're not
So, pull three tokens, if one is blue it’s a “success” let’s call it. It doesn’t matter what order it’s pulled as long as one is blue.
mason, more questions are needed
how many times are you pulling total? is it one at a time? three at a time?
and it _is_ without replacement?
so when you pull one, regardless of pass/fail, it stays out

It’s just a single pull.
From a mechanics stand-point, it’s pulling 3 marbles at once. 
Yes, it is without replacement.
so, that's HUGELY different that pulling 1 at a time
in which case it's 3/15
so 1/5 pulls

I don’t really see the difference, but like I said I’m not good with statistics.

My question is more about trying to figure out combined probabilities.
or rather not 3/15
derp
the reason why it's different:
if you're pulling 1 at a time, you're changing the the number inside the bag each pull
Eg. I know the probability of pulling exactly one token is ~58% in this instance.
pulling 1 out and replacing is going to be close to the same as pulling three out at once, but not quite
because pulling 1 at a time gives a chance to pull the same marble again
where as three at once that is removed

It's just a math problem, the probability would go down w/ the more marbles you're trying to pull. If you want to know for 1 pull and it's blue, 4/15 or 26.7% is correct. It's starts diminishing quickly because you go from the 26.7% and then you have to assume another will be pulled from the smaller batch. It doesn't matter if you pull one at a time or 3 at a time, the percentage of all 3 being blue will be the same no matter how they're picked

My original question stated that this is being done without replacement.
I understand they’re different if we were replacing them.
the thing is, when you say without replacement it implies trying more than once, which is differnt than grabbing all at once
well, no wait
it isn't
I'm dumb
the answer is 4/15 + 4/14 + 4/13
yeah, that's the end result
(probability you got a blue one on the first try) + (probability you missed, then got a blue one on the second try) + (probability you missed twice, then got the blue one on the third try)
that's the winning amount for 1 though

So if you're not replacing them after each pull it goes from a 26.7% chance for the first to be blue, then the chances of the second one being blue goes to 3/14 or 21.4% of it, but then you have to assume that the success is built off the first, so 21.4% of the 26.7% to get here, so you have a 5.7% of both of the pulls being blue. Then you repeat the process for the last
ok yeah
stop me if I'm wrong but isn't the probability still the same that at least one will be blue if you pull three at once
no, I corrected myself tom
you right
ah I see but the question was about the probabilities of exactly 1 2 or 3 being blue
it's trickier at 2
i.e. one blue and two
mmmm
beige
oooh
there is a cool trick

There are the following outcomes:
BBB*
BBR*
BRB*
BRR*
RBB*
RBR*
RRB*
RRR
assuming all the other marbles are beige
the * are the ones we care about
don beige doesn't start with R
so you find the probability of getting all red then subtract rom 1

1 ball being blue = 26.7%
2 balls being blue = 5.7%
3 balls being blue = .88%
thats 1 - (the chance of getting all 3 red)
there's a joke somewhere here about the probability of two balls being blue, does anyone want to make it?
I dunno, just ask your girlfriend?
It means you're probably married

<@U33EGB4TX> with those probabilities, which is my main question, how do you combine those?
Can you just add them and get ~32%
You don't add them
No matter how you pull them whether one at a time or all 3 at once, that's the percentage of them being blue
i'm pretty sure im right
the 1 blue config is a win
But you're not trying to pull red, you're trying to pull blue Don
jfc
IF YOU PULL ALL THREE RED then you lose
so you do 1 - all red
don's right
the other way to think about it is if you pull 1 blue at all, you win, so that's the only percentage that mattes

wait were you asking about the probability of getting at least one blue? I thought you were asking three questions: What is the probability that exactly one will be blue; ditto for exactly two; and then the same for exactly three
Since when did we start losing in this simulation? <@U3FV90TCZ> is such a bad teacher
<@U33EGB4TX> I get that. I’m looking for the total combined probability of those three events.
the answer is either P(BBB) + P(BBR) + ... + P(RRB)  , which if you want to calculate out then you are fine. Or you can do 1 - P(RRR)
however, if it means you win more money or something based on the amount of blue you pull, then the probablity thing matters a little more
Nerds
So you want to know X% of the time you will pull either 1, 2 or 3 blue?
in which case, yes you do add the %'s
but if all you care about is the % wins, the 1 pull is that
or you can find out the probability YOU DO NOT PICK OUT NONBLUE, which is the same thing

Basically.

I’m already finding the necessary percentages using combinations formulas.
I just didn’t know if I could just add them.
it's just that 2 and 3 are extra win
<@U3FV90TCZ> you can add them if they independent outcomes that can happen. if you add up all the potential outcomes it needs to add up to 1
so you take the potential outcomes like BRB or RRB or BBB and add them all up
Don't forget the RBB or BBR outcomes!
so [ P(BBB) + P(BBR) + ... + P(RRB) ] + P(RRR) = 1
<@U286Q175Y> cool. That’s all I needed to know.
How many of the balls are periwinkle?
PBR would become a potential outcome and mess up all the stats
Professional Bull Riding is a potential outcome?
Sometimes
Better than Pabst blue ribbon outcomes. Those benefit nobody.
Except maybe the plumber who’s got to snake your terlet after
I've never partaken, so I'll take your word for it.
pirate peanut butter = PB(RRR)
